conversation_input.content: Can head mra show previously tia or other damages

chosen.answer:
Yes, a head MRA (Magnetic Resonance Angiography) can potentially show evidence of previous TIAs (Transient Ischemic Attacks) or other types of brain damage. Here's some more information:

1. MRA for TIAs:
- MRA can detect narrowing or blockages in blood vessels that may have caused a TIA.
- It can show changes in blood flow patterns that might indicate a past TIA.
- However, TIAs are often brief and may not leave lasting visible changes.

2. Other brain damage detectable by MRA:
- Stroke: Can show areas of reduced blood flow or blockages.
- Aneurysms: Can detect bulges in blood vessel walls.
- Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs): Abnormal tangles of blood vessels.
- Atherosclerosis: Buildup of plaque in arteries.

3. Limitations:
- Very small or brief TIAs might not be visible on MRA.
- The timing of the scan is important; changes may be more visible shortly after an event.

4. Complementary imaging:
- MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is often used alongside MRA for a more comprehensive view.
- Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) can detect very recent ischemic events.

5. Importance of clinical history:
- The interpretation of MRA results is most effective when combined with a patient's clinical history and symptoms.

Always consult with a healthcare professional for accurate interpretation of MRA results and diagnosis.

reject.answer:
Yes, head MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) can show evidence of previous transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) or other types of brain damage. Here are some findings that may be visible on a head MRI:

1. TIA: Although TIAs typically do not cause permanent brain damage, in some cases, an MRI may reveal small areas of tissue damage or tiny infarcts (areas of dead tissue due to lack of blood supply) that are indicative of a previous TIA.

2. Ischemic stroke: MRI can detect areas of brain tissue that have been damaged due to a lack of blood supply, which may appear as bright or dark spots on the scan, depending on the timing of the imaging and the type of MRI sequence used.

3. Hemorrhagic stroke: MRI can show areas of bleeding in the brain, which may appear as bright or dark spots, depending on the age of the blood and the type of MRI sequence used.

4. White matter lesions: MRI can reveal small areas of damage to the brain's white matter, which may be caused by various factors such as aging, high blood pressure, or small vessel disease. These lesions may be associated with an increased risk of stroke or cognitive decline.

5. Other brain damage: MRI can detect various types of brain damage caused by conditions such as traumatic brain injury, brain tumors, infections, or neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's or multiple sclerosis.

It is important to note that the interpretation of MRI findings requires a trained radiologist or neurologist, as the appearance of brain lesions can vary depending on factors such as the timing of the scan and the specific MRI sequences used.

conversation_input.content: How to reset an iPhone

chosen.answer:
Resetting your iPhone can be a helpful troubleshooting step or a necessary action before selling or giving it away.  Here's a breakdown of how to reset your iPhone, along with important considerations:

**Before You Reset: BACK UP YOUR DATA!**

Resetting your iPhone will erase all of its data. It's crucial to back up your iPhone before you begin:

* **iCloud Backup:** Go to **Settings > [Your Name] > iCloud > iCloud Backup > Back Up Now**. Ensure you're connected to Wi-Fi.
* **iTunes/Finder Backup:** Connect your iPhone to your computer. Open iTunes (on macOS Mojave or earlier and Windows) or Finder (on macOS Catalina or later). Locate your iPhone and choose the backup option.

**Types of Resets:**

* **Soft Reset (Restart):**  This doesn't erase data and simply restarts your phone. It can fix minor glitches.
    * **iPhone 8 and later:** Press and quickly release the Volume Up button, then press and quickly release the Volume Down button. Finally, press and hold the Side button until the Apple logo appears.
    * **iPhone 7 and 7 Plus:** Press and hold the Side and Volume Down buttons until the Apple logo appears.
    * **iPhone 6s and earlier:** Press and hold the Home and the Top (or Side) buttons until the Apple logo appears.

* **Factory Reset (Erase All Content and Settings):** This erases everything on your iPhone and restores it to its factory settings.

**How to Factory Reset (Erase All Content and Settings):**

1. **Settings App:**
   * Open the **Settings app**.
   * Tap **General**.
   * Scroll down and tap **Transfer or Reset iPhone**.
   * Tap **Erase All Content and Settings**.
   * If prompted, enter your passcode or Apple ID password.
   * Tap **Erase iPhone** to confirm.

2. **Using a Computer (if your iPhone is unresponsive or you can't access Settings):**
   * Connect your iPhone to your computer.
   * Open iTunes (on macOS Mojave or earlier and Windows) or Finder (on macOS Catalina or later).
   * Locate your iPhone.
   * In iTunes, click on the **Summary** tab and then click **Restore iPhone**.
   * In Finder, click **Restore iPhone**.
   * Follow the onscreen instructions.

**Important Considerations:**

* **Apple ID & Find My iPhone:** If Find My iPhone is enabled, you'll need to enter your Apple ID password during the reset process to disable Activation Lock.
* **Cellular Data:**  If you're using cellular data for backup, make sure you have enough data in your plan.
* **Time:** The reset process can take some time, depending on how much data you have on your iPhone.

**After the Reset:**

* **Set Up as New:** Choose this option if you want to start fresh with a clean iPhone.
* **Restore from Backup:** Choose this option to restore your data and settings from a previous backup.

**When to Reset Your iPhone:**

* **Troubleshooting:** If your iPhone is experiencing persistent issues, a factory reset can often resolve them.
* **Selling or Giving Away:**  Always factory reset your iPhone before selling or giving it away to protect your privacy.
* **Before a Repair:** While not always necessary, some repair shops may ask you to reset your iPhone before bringing it in for service.

If you're unsure about any steps or encounter issues, it's best to consult Apple Support or visit an Apple Store for assistance.

reject.answer:
1. Press and hold the side button and either volume button until the power off slider appears.
2. Drag the power off slider to turn off your iPhone.
3. Press and hold the side button again until the Apple logo appears.
4. Release the side button.
5. Your iPhone will now be reset to its factory settings.

Note: This will erase all data on your iPhone, so make sure to back up your data before resetting.

### 1. **Soft Reset (Restart)**
This is simply restarting your iPhone.

- **For iPhone X and later:**
  1. Press and hold the Side button and either Volume button until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. After your iPhone turns off, press and hold the Side button again until you see the Apple logo.

- **For iPhone 8 and 8 Plus:**
  1. Press and hold the Side button until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. Press and hold the Side button again until you see the Apple logo.

- **For iPhone 7 and 7 Plus:**
  1. Press and hold the Volume Down and Side buttons until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. Press and hold the Side button again until you see the Apple logo.

- **For iPhone 6s and earlier:**
  1. Press and hold the Home and the Top (or Side) buttons until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. Press and hold the Top (or Side) button again until you see the Apple logo.

### 2. **Factory Reset (Erase All Content and Settings)**
This will erase all data from your iPhone and restore it to factory settings.

1. **Backup Your Data** (if needed):
   - Use iCloud or iTunes/Finder to back up your data.

2. **Go to Settings:**
   - Open the **Settings** app.

3. **Navigate to General:**
   - Scroll down and tap on **General**.

4. **Transfer or Reset iPhone:**
   - Scroll down and tap on **Transfer or Reset iPhone**.

5. **Erase All Content and Settings:**
   - Tap on **Erase All Content and Settings**.
   - You may need to enter your passcode and confirm that you want to erase your iPhone.

6. **Confirm:**
   - Follow the prompts to confirm the reset. Your iPhone will restart and begin the process of erasing all data.

### 3. **Reset Network Settings**
If you're having network issues, you can reset just the network settings.

1. **Go to Settings:**
   - Open the **Settings** app.

2. **Navigate to General:**
   - Tap on **General**.

3. **Transfer or Reset iPhone:**
   - Tap on **Transfer or Reset iPhone**.

4. **Reset:**
   - Tap on **Reset** and then select **Reset Network Settings**. You may need to enter your passcode to confirm.

### Important Notes:
- **Backup Your Data:** Always back up your data before performing a factory reset, as this process will erase everything on your device.
- **Apple ID and Activation Lock:** If you plan to sell or give away your iPhone, make sure to sign out of your Apple ID to disable Activation Lock.

If you have any specific issues or need further assistance, feel free to ask!

conversation_input.content: How to reset an iPhone

chosen.answer:
Resetting an iPhone can mean different things depending on what you want to achieve. Here are the common methods:

### 1. **Soft Reset (Restart)**
This is simply restarting your iPhone.

- **For iPhone X and later:**
  1. Press and hold the Side button and either Volume button until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. After your iPhone turns off, press and hold the Side button again until you see the Apple logo.

- **For iPhone 8 and 8 Plus:**
  1. Press and hold the Side button until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. Press and hold the Side button again until you see the Apple logo.

- **For iPhone 7 and 7 Plus:**
  1. Press and hold the Volume Down and Side buttons until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. Press and hold the Side button again until you see the Apple logo.

- **For iPhone 6s and earlier:**
  1. Press and hold the Home and the Top (or Side) buttons until the sliders appear.
  2. Drag the slider to turn off your iPhone.
  3. Press and hold the Top (or Side) button again until you see the Apple logo.

### 2. **Factory Reset (Erase All Content and Settings)**
This will erase all data from your iPhone and restore it to factory settings.

1. **Backup Your Data** (if needed):
   - Use iCloud or iTunes/Finder to back up your data.

2. **Go to Settings:**
   - Open the **Settings** app.

3. **Navigate to General:**
   - Scroll down and tap on **General**.

4. **Transfer or Reset iPhone:**
   - Scroll down and tap on **Transfer or Reset iPhone**.

5. **Erase All Content and Settings:**
   - Tap on **Erase All Content and Settings**.
   - You may need to enter your passcode and confirm that you want to erase your iPhone.

6. **Confirm:**
   - Follow the prompts to confirm the reset. Your iPhone will restart and begin the process of erasing all data.

### 3. **Reset Network Settings**
If you're having network issues, you can reset just the network settings.

1. **Go to Settings:**
   - Open the **Settings** app.

2. **Navigate to General:**
   - Tap on **General**.

3. **Transfer or Reset iPhone:**
   - Tap on **Transfer or Reset iPhone**.

4. **Reset:**
   - Tap on **Reset** and then select **Reset Network Settings**. You may need to enter your passcode to confirm.

### Important Notes:
- **Backup Your Data:** Always back up your data before performing a factory reset, as this process will erase everything on your device.
- **Apple ID and Activation Lock:** If you plan to sell or give away your iPhone, make sure to sign out of your Apple ID to disable Activation Lock.

If you have any specific issues or need further assistance, feel free to ask!

conversation_input.content: what is "c8" for partental controls

chosen.answer:
"c8" is not a standard abbreviation or term that is commonly used in the context of parental controls. It's possible that you may be thinking of a different term or abbreviation, or that "c8" has a specific meaning in a particular context or community.

If you can provide more information or context about what you are referring to, I may be able to help you better. In the meantime, here are some common terms and abbreviations related to parental controls:

1. PIN: Personal Identification Number, used to restrict access to certain features or content on a device or service.
2. Password: A secret code used to protect access to a device, account, or service.
3. Screen time: The amount of time a child spends using electronic devices, often used as a way to limit exposure to screens.
4. Content restrictions: Settings that limit the type of content that can be accessed on a device, such as movies, TV shows, music, or websites.
5. Access controls: Settings that restrict who can access certain features or content on a device or service.
6. Parental locks: Features that allow parents to restrict access to certain content or features on a device or service, such as blocking certain websites or apps.
7. Monitoring software: Programs that allow parents to monitor their child's online activity, such as tracking website visits or monitoring social media use.
8. Family safety: Settings and features that help protect children from inappropriate content, online predators, or other online risks.
9. Privacy settings: Settings that control who can see a child's personal information or online activity.

I hope this helps! If you have any further questions, feel free to ask.

reject.answer:
"C8" is often used as an abbreviation for "Customer-Configured Option 8" in the context of parental controls. Option 8 is a feature in the Digital Video Broadcasting (DVB) standard for setting access control and parental ratings on television content. This feature allows broadcasters to encrypt the content and provide a unique key to authorized users, thus preventing unauthorized access to certain channels or programs.

In the context of parental controls, Option 8 can be used to block access to programs based on their content rating. For example, a parent can use Option 8 to block access to programs rated as "adult" or "mature," while allowing access to programs rated as "children" or "general audience." The "C" in "C8" stands for "customer," indicating that the option is being configured by the end-user or customer, rather than the broadcaster.

To use Option 8 for parental controls, customers typically need to configure their set-top box or digital television to use the Option 8 feature and enter the appropriate access code or PIN. The specific steps for configuring Option 8 may vary depending on the make and model of the set-top box or television.

Let's break this down and address each question:

The speaker doesn't explicitly state in this passage why he's considering shooting the elephant. The fact that he's contemplating it despite his reluctance suggests there's an external force pushing him towards this action.

b) What is implied in that it's a "serious matter to shoot a working elephant"?

The implication here is multifaceted:
1. Economic value: The elephant is compared to "a huge and costly piece of machinery," indicating its significant economic worth to its owners or the community.
2. Utility: As a "working" elephant, it provides valuable labor and services.
3. Rarity: The seriousness implies that working elephants are not easily replaced.
4. Moral consideration: It suggests that taking the life of such a useful and valuable animal shouldn't be done lightly.

The irony lies in the contrast between the perceived threat of the elephant and its actual state:

1. The elephant is described as looking "no more dangerous than a cow" and "peacefully eating," yet the speaker is still considering shooting it.
2. The speaker believes the elephant's aggressive phase ("must") is likely passing, yet he's still contemplating killing it.
3. Despite the speaker's strong conviction that he "ought not to shoot him" and his personal desire not to do so, he's still considering the action.

This irony highlights the conflict between the speaker's personal judgment and the external pressures or expectations he feels, which is a central theme in Orwell's essay about the nature of imperialism and the position of those enforcing it.

If approved, do you intend to use your credit card for cash advances? (Optional)
What does this mean

chosen.answer:
If approved, do you intend to use your credit card for cash advances?

This question is typically asked by the lender to understand your intention for using the credit card once it is approved. A cash advance is a type of advance loan that allows you to borrow money from your credit card issuer, using your credit card as collateral.
If you answer "yes" to this question, it means that you plan to use the credit card for cash advances, which may have different terms and conditions than regular purchases. Cash advances often come with higher interest rates and fees, and may also have restrictions on how the funds can be used.
It's important to carefully consider your financial situation and whether using a credit card for cash advances is a good idea for you. It's always a good idea to review the terms and conditions of your credit card agreement and to understand the potential risks and consequences of using your credit card for cash advances.

reject.answer:
When you use a credit card for a cash advance, you are essentially borrowing money from your credit card issuer to make a cash withdrawal or pay for a purchase. This is different from using your credit card to make a normal purchase, where you pay for the goods or services immediately and are charged interest on the purchase amount.

Credit card cash advances often come with a higher interest rate than regular purchases, which means you may end up paying more in interest if you borrow money this way. Additionally, you may be charged a cash advance fee or a separate interest rate for cash advances, so it's important to review your credit card terms and conditions before you use the cash advance feature.

conversation_input.content: Which knob on an oscilloscope will adjust the vertical size of the signal on channel 1?

chosen.answer:
The knob that adjusts the vertical size of the signal on channel 1 of an oscilloscope is typically labeled "VOLTS/DIV" or "SCALE" for Channel 1. This control is also sometimes referred to as the "vertical scale" or "vertical sensitivity" control.

Here's a more detailed explanation:

1. Purpose: This knob controls the voltage scale of the vertical axis for Channel 1. It determines how many volts each vertical division on the oscilloscope screen represents.

2. Location: It's usually located in the vertical controls section of the oscilloscope, often grouped with other Channel 1 controls.

3. Operation: Turning this knob clockwise typically decreases the volts per division, which makes the signal appear larger vertically on the screen. Turning it counterclockwise increases the volts per division, making the signal appear smaller.

4. Units: The settings are usually in volts per division (V/div) or millivolts per division (mV/div), such as 5 V/div, 1 V/div, 500 mV/div, etc.

5. Effect: Adjusting this knob allows you to resize the signal vertically to fit it appropriately on the screen or to focus on particular voltage levels of interest.

Remember that while this knob adjusts the vertical size of the signal, it doesn't change the actual voltage of the input signal; it only changes how the signal is displayed on the screen.

reject.answer:
The knob that adjusts the vertical size of the signal on channel 1 of an oscilloscope is typically labeled "VOLTS/DIV" or "CH 1 VOLTS/DIV." This knob controls the vertical scale or sensitivity of the oscilloscope for channel 1.

Here's what you need to know about the VOLTS/DIV knob:

1. The VOLTS/DIV knob determines the voltage represented by each vertical division on the oscilloscope grid for the selected channel.

2. Turning the knob clockwise decreases the voltage per division, making the waveform appear smaller vertically. Conversely, turning the knob counterclockwise increases the voltage per division, making the waveform appear larger vertically.

3. The available settings for the VOLTS/DIV knob typically range from a few millivolts per division to several volts per division, depending on the oscilloscope model.

4. Many oscilloscopes have a separate VOLTS/DIV knob for each input channel, allowing you to adjust the vertical scale for each channel independently.

5. Some oscilloscopes also have a "variable" or "fine" adjustment option for the VOLTS/DIV setting, which allows you to make smaller, more precise adjustments to the vertical scale.

By adjusting the VOLTS/DIV knob, you can set the appropriate vertical scale to display the signal effectively on the oscilloscope screen, ensuring that the waveform is neither too small nor too large for accurate analysis.

reject.answer:
On an oscilloscope, the vertical size of the signal on channel 1 can be adjusted using the "vertical position" or "vert position" knob for that channel. This control is usually labeled as "VPOS" or " vertical position" followed by the channel number (e.g., "VPOS1" for channel 1).

The vertical position knob adjusts the position of the signal vertically on the screen, allowing you to move the signal up or down. By turning the knob clockwise, you will increase the vertical size of the signal, and by turning it counterclockwise, you will decrease the vertical size.

It's important to note that there is a separate vertical position knob for each channel on a dual-channel oscilloscope. Make sure you are adjusting the correct channel by verifying the label next to the knob.

conversation_input.content: Whose company is Line app?

chosen.answer:
Line is a messaging and communication app that was originally developed by NHN Japan, a subsidiary of South Korean internet search giant Naver Corporation.

Key points about Line's ownership:

1. Line Corporation was established in 2000 as a subsidiary of Naver Corporation.

2. In 2013, Line Corporation became an independent company, though Naver remained the majority shareholder.

3. In 2016, Line Corporation went public, listing on both the New York Stock Exchange and the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

4. In 2021, Line Corporation merged with Yahoo Japan (which is majority-owned by SoftBank) to form a new company called Z Holdings Corporation.

5. As of now, Z Holdings Corporation is jointly owned by Naver Corporation and SoftBank Group, each holding approximately 50% of the shares.

conversation_input.content: Is it illegal to intentionally upload a picture of my social securtiy number online

chosen.answer:
Yes, it is generally considered illegal to intentionally upload a picture of your social security number online, as it is a violation of privacy and could potentially lead to identity theft or other fraudulent activity.

Social security numbers are considered sensitive personal information, and the federal government has strict laws in place to protect them. The Social Security Administration (SSA) states that it is illegal to disclose or use someone's social security number without their consent, and this includes uploading it online.

Additionally, many states have their own laws that protect social security numbers and other personal identifying information. For example, some states have laws that make it a crime to intentionally disclose someone's social security number without their consent, or to use someone's social security number for unlawful purposes.

If you are concerned about protecting your social security number, it is generally recommended that you do not upload it online or share it with anyone unless it is absolutely necessary. If you need to provide your social security number to a government agency or a business, it is best to do so in person or through a secure online portal. You should also be cautious when sharing personal information online and make sure that you are using secure websites and networks.

In summary, it is generally illegal to intentionally upload a picture of your social security number online, and it is important to protect your personal information to prevent identity theft and other fraudulent activity.

chosen.answer:
In the Aadd9 chord on guitar, the 6th string (the low E string) is typically not played. The standard fingering for an Aadd9 chord is:

- 1st finger on the 2nd fret of the 4th string (D)
- 2nd finger on the 2nd fret of the 3rd string (G) 
- 3rd finger on the 2nd fret of the 2nd string (B)

The 1st string (high E) is played open. The 5th string (A) can either be played open or muted with the tip of the 1st finger. And the 6th string (low E) is not strummed.

So in summary, yes the 6th string is usually silent when playing the Aadd9 chord in its standard voicing on guitar. The chord is played using the middle 4 strings.

conversation_input.content: Is sclc operateable

chosen.answer:
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is typically considered more aggressive than non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and is often diagnosed at an advanced stage. The operability of SCLC largely depends on the stage at which it is diagnosed:

1. **Limited Stage SCLC**: This stage means the cancer is confined to one lung and possibly nearby lymph nodes. In some cases, if the cancer is detected early enough and is localized, surgery may be an option, often in conjunction with chemotherapy and radiation.

2. **Extensive Stage SCLC**: This stage indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the lung to other parts of the body. In this case, surgery is generally not considered an option, and treatment typically focuses on chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

Overall, while some patients with limited stage SCLC may be candidates for surgery, many are treated with a combination of chemotherapy and radiation. Treatment decisions are highly individualized and depend on various factors, including the patient's overall health, the specific characteristics of the cancer, and the presence of any metastases. Always consult with a healthcare professional for the most accurate diagnosis and treatment options.

reject.answer:
SCLC (Small Cell Lung Cancer) is generally considered to be operable, but the specific treatment plan and prognosis will depend on several factors, including the stage and location of the cancer, the patient's overall health, and their personal preferences.

Surgery is often the primary treatment for SCLC, and the goal is to remove the tumor and any affected lymph nodes. The two main types of surgery for SCLC are:

1. Lobectomy: This involves removing one lobe of the lung, which is the portion of the lung where the cancer is located.
2. Pneumonectomy: This involves removing an entire lung.

In some cases, surgery may not be possible or may not be the best option, and other treatments such as radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of both may be recommended instead.

It's important to note that SCLC is a highly aggressive form of lung cancer, and even with treatment, the prognosis is generally poor. The 5-year survival rate for SCLC is less than 10%, but this number can vary depending on the stage and other factors.

It's important for patients with SCLC to work closely with their healthcare team to determine the best course of treatment and to understand the potential risks and benefits of each option. Clinical trials may also be an option for some patients, and these can provide access to new and innovative treatments that may not be widely available otherwise.

conversation_input.content: Is sclc operateable

chosen.answer:
Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC) is generally not considered operable in most cases. Here's why:

1. Late diagnosis: SCLC is often diagnosed at an advanced stage when it has already spread beyond the lung.

2. Rapid growth: SCLC tends to grow and spread quickly, making it difficult to catch early enough for surgery to be effective.

3. Systemic disease: By the time SCLC is diagnosed, it's often considered a systemic disease, meaning cancer cells have likely spread throughout the body.

4. Standard treatment: The primary treatments for SCLC are typically chemotherapy and radiation therapy, rather than surgery.

However, there are some exceptions:

1. Very early-stage SCLC: In rare cases where SCLC is caught very early (Stage I), surgery might be considered, followed by chemotherapy.

2. Combined SCLC: If the cancer has both small cell and non-small cell components, surgery might be an option for the non-small cell portion.

3. Clinical trials: Some clinical trials may explore surgical options for SCLC in specific circumstances.

It's important to note that treatment decisions should always be made in consultation with an oncologist, as they can provide the most up-to-date and personalized advice based on the specific case and latest research.

reject.answer:
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is rarely operable because it is usually diagnosed at an advanced stage when the cancer has already spread to other parts of the body. SCLC tends to grow and spread quickly, making surgery an ineffective treatment option in most cases.

The main treatment options for SCLC include:

1. Chemotherapy: This is the primary treatment for SCLC, as it can help shrink tumors and control the cancer's spread.

2. Radiation therapy: This may be used in combination with chemotherapy to target specific areas affected by cancer, such as the brain or bone.

3. Immunotherapy: In some cases, immunotherapy drugs may be used to help the body's immune system fight cancer cells.

4. Clinical trials: Patients may be eligible to participate in clinical trials testing new treatments or combinations of existing therapies.

Surgery may be considered in very rare cases of SCLC when the cancer is diagnosed at a very early stage and is confined to a small area of the lung. However, this is an uncommon scenario, and most patients with SCLC are not candidates for surgery.

conversation_input.content: Was it possible to record 1080p video in the year 1999?

chosen.answer:
No, it was not possible to record 1080p video in 1999. The first consumer camera that could record high-definition video, the Sanyo Xacti HD1, was not released until 2006. The HD1 was capable of recording 1080i video, not 1080p. The first consumer camcorder that could record true 1080p video, the JVC Everio GZ-HD7, was released in 2008.

In 1999, the standard for high-definition video was 1080i, and it was not until a few years later that 1080p became the standard for high-definition video. The term "1080p" refers to a specific format for high-definition video that has a resolution of 1920 x 1080 pixels and displays video progressively (one line at a time). In contrast, 1080i video is displayed in interlaced fields, with each field consisting of half of the lines of video.

In 1999, the most common format for video recording was standard definition (SD), which has a resolution of 720 x 480 pixels for video recorded in the NTSC format or 720 x 576 pixels for video recorded in the PAL format. SD video was typically recorded on tape using analog tape formats such as VHS or Hi8, or on digital tape formats such as Digital8 or MiniDV.

It is worth noting that 1080p video was used in the film and television industries before it became available to consumers. For example, the first feature film to be shot and displayed in 1080p was the 2000 film "O Brother, Where Art Thou?". However, this was done using specialized equipment and techniques that were not available to consumers at the time.

It wasn't until the mid to late 2000s that 1080p video recording became more widely available in consumer camcorders and other devices, such as high-definition TVs and video game consoles. By the early 2010s, 1080p had become the standard resolution for many consumer video devices, and it remains a widely used resolution today.

conversation_input.content: what does it mean when something is protected by copyright

chosen.answer:
When something is protected by copyright, it means that the creator of that work has exclusive rights to use, distribute, and reproduce it. Copyright applies to original works of authorship, including literature, music, art, films, software, and more. Here are some key points about copyright protection:

1. **Exclusive Rights**: The copyright holder has the right to control how the work is used, including the right to reproduce it, distribute copies, perform it publicly, display it publicly, and create derivative works.

2. **Automatic Protection**: Copyright protection is automatic upon the creation of an original work that is fixed in a tangible medium of expression (like writing it down or recording it). Registration with a copyright office is not required, but it can provide additional legal benefits.

3. **Duration**: Copyright protection does not last indefinitely. In most jurisdictions, it lasts for the life of the author plus a certain number of years (often 70 years in the U.S. and many other countries). After this period, the work enters the public domain and can be used freely by anyone.

4. **Limitations and Exceptions**: There are certain limitations to copyright, such as "fair use" in the U.S., which allows for limited use of copyrighted material without permission under specific circumstances (like criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, or research).

5. **Infringement**: Using a copyrighted work without permission from the copyright holder can lead to legal consequences, including lawsuits and financial penalties.

Overall, copyright is designed to protect the rights of creators and encourage the production of new works by ensuring that they can benefit from their creations.

reject.answer:
When something is protected by copyright, it means that the creator or owner of that work has been granted certain legal rights under copyright law, which give them exclusive control over how their work can be used, distributed, and displayed.

In general, copyright protection gives the owner the right to:

1. Reproduce the work: The owner has the exclusive right to make copies of the work, including digital copies, prints, or other forms of reproduction.
2. Distribute copies: The owner has the exclusive right to distribute copies of the work, either by selling them or giving them away.
3. Display the work publicly: The owner has the exclusive right to display the work publicly, such as in a gallery, museum, or other public space.
4. Perform the work publicly: The owner has the exclusive right to perform the work publicly, such as in a play, concert, or other performance.
5. Create derivative works: The owner has the exclusive right to create new works that are based on the original work, such as a sequel, adaptation, or remix.
6. License or sell the rights: The owner can license or sell the rights to the work to others, allowing them to use the work in certain ways while still retaining some control over its use.

Copyright protection also gives the owner the right to take legal action against anyone who uses the work without their permission, such as by suing for copyright infringement.

It's worth noting that copyright protection only applies to original works that are fixed in a tangible form, such as a written work, a painting, a photograph, or a recording. Ideas or concepts cannot be copyrighted. Additionally, certain uses of a copyrighted work, such as for criticism, commentary, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, or research, may be considered fair use and are not considered infringing on the copyright.

Overall, copyright protection gives creators and owners the ability to control how their work is used and to profit from its use, while also providing a way for others to use the work in limited ways for certain purposes.

chosen.answer:
**Protection under Copyright Law**

When something is protected by copyright, it means that the rights to use, reproduce, distribute, or create derivative works from that material are legally granted to the copyright holder. This protection extends to creative works such as:

* **Literary works:** Books, articles, poetry, plays
* **Musical works:** Songs, compositions, lyrics
* **Artistic works:** Paintings, sculptures, photographs, drawings
* **Audiovisual works:** Movies, television shows, documentaries
* **Sound recordings:** Music, podcasts, audiobooks

**Rights Granted by Copyright**

Copyright law typically grants the following exclusive rights to the copyright holder:

* **Reproduction:** Copying or making copies of the work
* **Distribution:** Sale, rental, or other forms of distribution
* **Public performance:** Exhibition or performance of the work in public
* **Public display:** Public display of the work
* **Derivative works:** Creation of new works based on the original work

**Duration of Protection**

The duration of copyright protection varies from country to country. In the United States, copyright protection lasts for the life of the author plus 70 years after their death. For works created by corporations or other legal entities, copyright lasts for 95 years from the year of publication or 120 years from the year of creation, whichever is shorter.

**Exceptions to Copyright**

Certain uses of copyrighted materials may be permitted without infringing copyright, such as:

* **Fair use:** Limited copying or use for criticism, comment, news reporting, education, or research
* **Public domain:** Works that are not protected by copyright due to their age or lack of originality
* **Licenses:** Permissions granted by the copyright holder to use the work under specific conditions

**Consequences of Copyright Infringement**

Unauthorised use of copyrighted materials can lead to legal consequences, including:

* **Injunctions:** Court orders prohibiting further use of the work
* **Damages:** Monetary compensation for copyright infringement
* **Criminal penalties:** In severe cases, copyright infringement can be a criminal offense punishable by fines or imprisonment

conversation_input.content:
Questions:
1. In this essay, Dillard separates the behavior of boys from that of both girls and adults. What characteristics does she identify that distinguish the actions ofboys? Why is she able to play with them?
2. What is Dillard's main point? Where does she state it explicitly?
3. Why did she write this if she did not like memoirs?
4. Did she throw iceballs indiscriminitly? If she didn‚Äôt, why mention it?
5. Why did they not run after being caught?

Text:
Some boys taught me to play football. This was fine sport. You thought up a new strategy for every play and whispered it to the others. You went out for a pass, fooling everyone. Best, you got to throw yourself mightily at someone's running legs. Either you brought him down or you hit the ground flat out on your chin, with your arms empty before you. It was all or nothing. If you hesitated in fear, you would miss and get hurt: you would take a hard fall while the kid got away, or you would get kicked in the face while the kid got away. But if you flung yourself wholeheartedly at the back of his knees - if you gathered and joined body and soul and pointed them diving fearlessly -- then you likely wouldn't get hurt, and you'd stop the ball. Your fate, and your team's score, depended on your concentration and courage. Nothing girls did could compare with it.
Boys welcomed me at baseball, too, for I had, through enthusi- 2
astic practice, what was weirdly known as a boy's arm. In winter, in the snow, there was neither baseball nor football, so the boys and I threw snowballs at passing cars. I got in trouble throwing snowballs, and have seldom been happier since.
On one weekday morning after Christmas, six inches of new snow had just fallen. We were standing up to our boot tops in snow on a front yard on trafficked Reynolds Street, waiting forcars. The cars traveled Reynolds Street slowly and evenly; they were targets all but wrapped in red ribbons, cream puffs. We couldn't miss.
I was seven; the boys were eight, nine, and ten. The oldest two Fahey boys were there - Mikey and Peter - polite blond boys who
lived near me on Lloyd Street, and who already had four brothers and sisters. My parents approved Mikey and Peter Fahey. Chickie McBride was there, a tough kid, and Billy Paul and Mackie Kean
too, from across Reynolds, where the boys grew up dark and furi- ous, grew up skinny, knowing, and skilled.We had all drifted from our houses that morning looking for action, and had found it here on Reynolds Street.
It was cloudy but cold. The cars' tires laid behind them on the snowy street a complex trail of beige chunks like crenellated castle walls. I had stepped on some earlier; they squeaked. We could have wished for more traffic. When a car came, we all popped it one. In
the intervals between cars we reverted to the natural solitude of children.
I started making an iceball - a perfect iceball, from perfectly 6 white snow, perfectly spherical, and squeezed perfectly translucent
os no snow remained all the way through. (The Fahey boys and I considered it unfair actually to throw an iceball at somebody, but it had been known to happen.)
I had just embarked on the iceball project when we heard tire
chains come clanking from afar. A black Buick was moving toward us down the street. We all spread out, banged together some regu- lar snowballs, tookaim, and, when the Buickdrew nigh, fired.
A soft snowball hit the driver's windshield right before the
driver's face. It made a smashed star with a hump in the middle.
Often, of course, we hit our target, but this time, t h eonly time in
all of life, the car pulled overand stopped. Its wide black door opened;
a man got out of it, running. He didn't even close thecardoor.
He ran after us, and we ran away from him, up the snowy 01 Reynolds sidewalk. At the corner, I looked back; incredibly, he was
still after us. He was in city clothes: a suit and tie, street shoes.
Any normal adult would have quit, having sprung us into flight and made his point. This man was gaining on us. He was a thin man,
all action. Al of asudden, we were running for our lives.
Wordless, we split up. We were on our turf; we could lose our- 1 selves in the neighborhood backyards, everyone for himself. I paused and considered. Everyone had vanished except Mikey Fahey, who was just rounding the corner of a yellow brick house. Poor Mikey, I trailed him. 'The driver of the Buick sensibly picked the two of us to follow. The man apparently had all day.
He chased Mikey and me around the yellow house and up a 21 backyard path we knew by heart: under a low tree, up a bank, through a hedge, down some snowy steps, and across the grocery store's delivery driveway. We smashed through a gap in another hedge, entered a scruffy backyard and ran around its back porch
and tight between houses to Edgerton Avenue; we ran across Edgerton to an alley and up our own sliding woodpile to the Halls' front yard; he kept coming. We ran up Lloyd Street and wound through mazy backyards toward the steep hilltop at Willard and
Lang.
He chased us silently, block after block. He chased us silently
13 over picket fences, through thorny hedges, between houses, around garbage cans, and across streets. Every time I glanced back, chok-
ing for breath, I expected he would have quit. He must have been
as breathless as we were. His jacket strained over his body. It was
an immense discovery, pounding into my hot head with every slid-
ing, joyous step, that this ordinary adult evidently knew what I
thought only children who trained at football knew: that you have
to fling yourself at what you're doing, you have to point yourself, forget yourself, aim, dive.
Mikey and I had nowhere to go, in our own neighborhood or out
41
of it, but away from this man who was chasing us. He impelled us forward; we compelled him to follow our route. The air was cold; every breath tore my throat. We kept running, block after block; we kept improvising, backyard after backyard, running a frantic course and choosing ti simultaneously, failing always to find small places or hard places to slow him down, and discovering always, ex- hilarated, dismayed, that only bare speed could save us - for he would never give up, this man- and we were losing speed.
He chased us through the backyard labyrinths of ten blocks be- fore he caught us by our jackets. He caught us and we all stopped.
We three stood staggering, half blinded, coughing, in an ob-
16 scure hilltop backyard: a man in his twenties, a boy, a girl. He had released our jackets, our pursuer, our captor, our hero: he knew we weren't going anywhere. We all played by the rules. Mikey and I
unzipped our jackets. I pulled off my sopping mittens. Our tracks multiplied in the backyard's new snow. We had been breaking new snow all morning. We didn't look at each other. I was cherishing my excitement. The man's lower pants legs were wet; his cuffs were full of snow, and there was a prow of snow beneath them on his shoes and socks. Some trees bordered the little flat backyard, some messy winter trees. There was no one around: a clearing in a grove, and we the only players.
It was a long time before he could speak. I had some difficulty 71 at first recalling why we were there. My lips felt swollen; Icouldn't
see out of the sides of my eyes; I kept coughing.
"You stupid kids," he began perfunctorily. 18 We listened perfunctorily indeed, if we listened at all, for the 19 chewing out was redundant, a mere formality, and beside the point.
The point was that he had chased us passionately without giving
up, and so he had caught us. Now he came down to earth. I wanted
the glory to last forever.
But how could the glory have lasted forever? We could have run 20 through every backyard in North America until we got to Panama.
But when he trapped us at the lip ofthe Panama Canal, what pre- cisely could he have done to prolong the drama ofthe chase and cap
its glory? I brooded about this for the next few years. He could only have friedMikey Fahey and me in boilingoil, say, or dismembered us piecemeal, or staked us to anthills. None of which I really wanted, and none ofwhich any adult was likely to do, even in the spirit of fun. He could only chew us out there in the Panamanian jungle, after
months or years of exalting pursuit. He could only begin, "You stupid kids," and continue in his ordinary Pittsburgh accent with his normal righteous anger and the usual common sense.
Ifin that snowy backyard the driver of the black Buick had cut 12 off our heads, Mikey's and mine, I would have died happy, for noth-
ing has required so much ofme since as being chased all over Pitts- burghin the middle of winter- running terrified, exhausted- by
this sainted, skinny, furious red-headed man who wished to have a word with us. I don't know how he found his way back to his car.
Responding to Reading
As a child, did you ever do something exhilarating, satisfying, or fun even though you knew that it was "wrong? Compare your experience to Dil- lard's.To what extent shouldchildren be held responsible for their deliber-
ate misbehaviors? What would have been an appropriate consequence for Dillard and her companions? If you had chased them down, what would you have done?

chosen.answer:
Based on the details provided in the essay, here are my responses to your questions:

1. Dillard portrays the boys as daring, physical, and welcoming her to join their rough sports and mischief-making. She is able to play with them because she practices enthusiastically to keep up with their skill level, like having "a boy's arm" in baseball. The boys' activities require "concentration and courage" in a way that "Nothing girls did could compare with."

2. Dillard's main point seems to be that as a child, she found an exhilarating joy and meaning in committing herself wholeheartedly to action, whether it was sports or mischief like the snowball fight. She explicitly states "you have to fling yourself at what you're doing, you have to point yourself, forget yourself, aim, dive." 

3. The question of why she wrote this if she did not like memoirs is not directly answerable from the text. The passage does not mention her feelings about memoirs.

4. The text states that Dillard and the Fahey boys "considered it unfair actually to throw an iceball at somebody, but it had been known to happen." This suggests she did not throw iceballs indiscriminately, seeing it as unfair, even though it sometimes occurred.

5. After being caught, it seems Dillard and Mikey did not run because an unspoken code of rules and roles was being followed - the man had fairly caught them after an epic chase, so they accepted it as the conclusion. As Dillard puts it, "We all played by the rules... he knew we weren't going anywhere."

In summary, the essay vividly portrays the thrill Dillard found as a child in committing herself boldly to daring physical activities, even mischievous ones, and the meaningful life lesson it taught her. The man chasing them is portrayed almost as an archetype playing his role in the drama.

reject.answer:
Question 1:
Dillard separates the behavior of boys from that of girls and adults by highlighting the distinct characteristics of boys' play. She describes how boys engage in physical activities like football and snowball fights with a sense of enthusiasm and wholeheartedness, while girls and adults do not participate in such activities. The boys' behavior is characterized by their willingness to take risks, their courage, and their ability to strategize.

Question 2:
Dillard's main point is that children should be allowed to engage in activities that bring them joy and excitement, even if these activities are considered "wrong" or "dangerous" by adults. She argues that children should be free to explore and experience the world without being constrained by societal expectations or fear of punishment. Dillard states this explicitly when she writes, "It was an immense discovery, pounding into my hot head with every sliding, joyous step, that this ordinary adult evidently knew what I thought only children who trained at football knew: that you have to fling yourself at what you're doing, you have to point yourself, forget yourself, aim, dive."

Question 3:
Dillard wrote this essay despite not liking memoirs because she wanted to capture the excitement and joy of childhood experiences. She wanted to convey the sense of freedom and exploration that children have when they engage in activities that they enjoy. By writing about her own experiences, Dillard was able to convey the emotions and sensations of childhood in a way that a more objective account might not have been able to capture.

Question 4:
Dillard and her companions did not throw iceballs indiscriminately. They targeted cars passing by on the street, and they aimed carefully, trying to hit the drivers. Dillard mentions the iceballs to highlight the sense of danger and excitement that came with playing in the snow. The iceballs were a way for the children to test their skills and push the boundaries of what was allowed.

Question 5:
The boys and Dillard did not run after being caught because they had been playing by the rules. They had been chased, and they knew that they had been caught fair and square. Running away would have been seen as a violation of the rules of the game and would have spoiled the sense of sportsmanship that had been established. By staying and facing the consequences, the children showed respect for the game and for the adult who had chased them.

In my opinion, children should be held responsible for their deliberate misbehaviors, but the consequences should be appropriate to their age and the circumstances. In Dillard's case, a stern warning and a reminder of the dangers of playing in the street might have been sufficient. If I had chased them down, I would have tried to convey the message that their behavior was not acceptable while still acknowledging their enthusiasm and energy. I might have suggested alternative activities that were safer and more productive, while still allowing them to have fun.

Running away would have been seen as a violation of the rules of the game and would have spoiled the sense of sportsmanship that had been established. By staying and facing the consequences, the children showed respect for the game and for the adult who had chased them.

In my opinion, children should be held responsible for their deliberate misbehaviors, but the consequences should be appropriate to their age and the circumstances. In Dillard's case, a stern warning and a reminder of the dangers of playing in the street might have been sufficient. If I had chased them down, I would have tried to convey the message that their behavior was not acceptable while still acknowledging their enthusiasm and energy. I might have suggested alternative activities that were safer and more productive, while still allowing them to have fun.

chosen.answer:
## Analysis of Annie Dillard's "The Chase"

Here's a breakdown of the questions and the text:

**1. In this essay, Dillard separates the behavior of boys from that of both girls and adults. What characteristics does she identify that distinguish the actions of boys? Why is she able to play with them?**

Dillard identifies boys as being driven by a desire for physical, all-or-nothing action. In football, they throw themselves wholeheartedly into tackles; in snowball fights, they aim with precision and ferocity. This contrasts with the activities of girls, which she implicitly characterizes as less physically demanding and less focused on direct confrontation.

Dillard is able to play with them because she shares this passion for wholehearted engagement. Her "boy's arm" in baseball and her eagerness to participate in snowball fights demonstrate her willingness to embrace the boys' code of physicality and courage.

**2. What is Dillard's main point? Where does she state it explicitly?**

Dillard's main point is the enduring power of fully committing oneself to an experience, regardless of its consequences. This is most explicitly stated in paragraph 23: "It was an immense discovery, pounding into my hot head with every sliding, joyous step, that this ordinary adult evidently knew what I thought only children who trained at football knew: that you have to fling yourself at what you're doing, you have to point yourself, forget yourself, aim, dive."

The chase itself, while exhilarating, is secondary to the revelation about the importance of complete immersion and commitment.

**3. Why did she write this if she did not like memoirs?**

While Dillard generally dislikes memoirs, this piece transcends a simple recounting of personal events. It uses the anecdote of the chase as a vehicle to explore a larger theme about the human experience. It's less about Dillard herself and more about the universal desire for passionate engagement.

**4. Did she throw iceballs indiscriminately? If she didn‚Äôt, why mention it?**

The text suggests they didn't throw iceballs indiscriminately. Dillard mentions their specific targeting of the Buick and the fact that they considered it unfair to throw an iceball directly at someone. This detail highlights the unexpectedness of the driver's reaction and reinforces the boys' (and Dillard's) own code of conduct within their games.

**5. Why did they not run after being caught?**

They didn't run after being caught because they understood the unspoken rules of the game. They had been caught fair and square, and further resistance would have been pointless and disrespectful. They accepted the consequences of their actions and submitted to the authority of the adult.

**Overall, "The Chase" is a powerful essay that uses a childhood memory to explore the deeper meaning of commitment and the exhilaration of fully engaging in an experience. It highlights the value of embracing challenges and pushing oneself beyond perceived limitations, even if it means facing consequences.**

The "Responding to Reading" questions are designed to encourage further reflection on the themes of the essay and their relevance to personal experiences and moral dilemmas. They prompt the reader to consider the balance between youthful exuberance and responsible behavior, and the appropriate consequences for transgressions.

Characteristics that distinguish the actions of boys, according to Dillard:
- They are willing to take risks and to engage in physical activity, even if it means getting hurt.
- They are able to focus and to concentrate on a task, and to work together as a team.
- They are not afraid to fail.
- They are able to accept responsibility for their actions and they do not always need adult supervision.

Dillard is able to play with boys because she shares these qualities. She is willing to get dirty and to take risks, she is able to concentrate and to work as a team, and she is not afraid to make mistakes.

**2. What is Dillard's main point? Where does she state it explicitly?**

Dillard's main point is that there is a lot of value in children being allowed to play unsupervised, to take risks, and to learn from their mistakes. She states this explicitly in the last paragraph of the essay, when she says that she would have died happy if the driver of the black Buick had cut off her head, because nothing has required so much of her since as being chased all over Pittsburgh in the middle of winter- running terrified, exhausted- by this sainted, skinny, furious red-headed man who wished to have a word with us.

**3. Why did she write this if she did not like memoirs?**

Dillard does not say that she does not like memoirs. In fact, this essay could be considered a memoir, as it is a personal recollection of an event that happened in her childhood. However, it is also an essay about the value of play, and it is not focused on the author's personal life.

**4. Did she throw iceballs indiscriminately? If she didn‚Äôt, why mention it?**

Dillard does not say that she threw iceballs indiscriminately. In fact, she says that the Fahey boys and she considered it unfair to actually throw an iceball at somebody. However, she mentions it because it is a way to show how she and the boys were able to have fun together, even though they knew that it was something that they were not supposed to do.

**5. Why did they not run after being caught?**

Dillard and Mikey Fahey did not run after being caught because they were exhausted and they knew that they could not outrun the man who was chasing them. They also knew that they had done something wrong, and they were expecting to be punished.

I had just embarked on the iceball project when we heard tire
chains come clanking from afar. A black Buick was moving toward us down the street. We all spread out, banged together some regu- lar snowballs, tookaim, and, when the Buickdrew nigh, fired.
A soft snowball hit the driver's windshield right before the
driver's face. It made a smashed star with a hump in the middle.
Often, of course, we hit our target, but this time, t h eonly time in
all of life, the car pulled overand stopped. Its wide black door opened;
a man got out of it, running. He didn't even close thecardoor.
He ran after us, and we ran away from him, up the snowy 01 Reynolds sidewalk. At the corner, I looked back; incredibly, he was
still after us. He was in city clothes: a suit and tie, street shoes.
Any normal adult would have quit, having sprung us into flight and made his point. This man was gaining on us. He was a thin man,
all action. Al of asudden, we were running for our lives.
Wordless, we split up. We were on our turf; we could lose our- 1 selves in the neighborhood backyards, everyone for himself. I paused and considered. Everyone had vanished except Mikey Fahey, who was just rounding the corner of a yellow brick house. Poor Mikey, I trailed him. 'The driver of the Buick sensibly picked the two of us to follow. The man apparently had all day.
He chased Mikey and me around the yellow house and up a 21 backyard path we knew by heart: under a low tree, up a bank, through a hedge, down some snowy steps, and across the grocery store's delivery driveway. We smashed through a gap in another hedge, entered a scruffy backyard and ran around its back porch
and tight between houses to Edgerton Avenue; we ran across Edgerton to an alley and up our own sliding woodpile to the Halls' front yard; he kept coming. We ran up Lloyd Street and wound through mazy backyards toward the steep hilltop at Willard and
Lang.
He chased us silently, block after block. He chased us silently
13 over picket fences, through thorny hedges, between houses, around garbage cans, and across streets. Every time I glanced back, chok-
ing for breath, I expected he would have quit. He must have been
as breathless as we were. His jacket strained over his body. It was
an immense discovery, pounding into my hot head with every slid-
ing, joyous step, that this ordinary adult evidently knew what I
thought only children who trained at football knew: that you have
to fling yourself at what you're doing, you have to point yourself, forget yourself, aim, dive.
Mikey and I had nowhere to go, in our own neighborhood or out
41
of it, but away from this man who was chasing us. He impelled us forward; we compelled him to follow our route. The air was cold; every breath tore my throat. We kept running, block after block; we kept improvising, backyard after backyard, running a frantic course and choosing ti simultaneously, failing always to find small places or hard places to slow him down, and discovering always, ex- hilarated, dismayed, that only bare speed could save us - for he would never give up, this man- and we were losing speed.
He chased us through the backyard labyrinths of ten blocks be- fore he caught us by our jackets. He caught us and we all stopped.
We three stood staggering, half blinded, coughing, in an ob-
16 scure hilltop backyard: a man in his twenties, a boy, a girl. He had released our jackets, our pursuer, our captor, our hero: he knew we weren't going anywhere. We all played by the rules. Mikey and I
unzipped our jackets. I pulled off my sopping mittens. Our tracks multiplied in the backyard's new snow. We had been breaking new snow all morning. We didn't look at each other. I was cherishing my excitement. The man's lower pants legs were wet; his cuffs were full of snow, and there was a prow of snow beneath them on his shoes and socks. Some trees bordered the little flat backyard, some messy winter trees. There was no one around: a clearing in a grove, and we the only players.
It was a long time before he could speak. I had some difficulty 71 at first recalling why we were there. My lips felt swollen; Icouldn't
see out of the sides of my eyes; I kept coughing.
"You stupid kids," he began perfunctorily. 18 We listened perfunctorily indeed, if we listened at all, for the 19 chewing out was redundant, a mere formality, and beside the point.
The point was that he had chased us passionately without giving
up, and so he had caught us. Now he came down to earth. I wanted
the glory to last forever.
But how could the glory have lasted forever? We could have run 20 through every backyard in North America until we got to Panama.

its glory? I brooded about this for the next few years. He could only have friedMikey Fahey and me in boilingoil, say, or dismembered us piecemeal, or staked us to anthills. months or years of exalting pursuit. He could only begin, "You stupid kids," and continue in his ordinary Pittsburgh accent with his normal righteous anger and the usual common sense.
Ifin that snowy backyard the driver of the black Buick had cut 12 off our heads, Mikey's and mine, I would have died happy, for noth-

chosen.answer:
## Analysis of Annie Dillard's "The Chase"

Here's a breakdown of the questions and the text:

**1. In this essay, Dillard separates the behavior of boys from that of both girls and adults. What characteristics does she identify that distinguish the actions of boys? Why is she able to play with them?**

Dillard identifies boys as being driven by a desire for physical, all-or-nothing action. In football, they throw themselves wholeheartedly into tackles; in snowball fights, they aim with precision and ferocity. This contrasts with the activities of girls, which she implicitly characterizes as less physically demanding and less focused on direct confrontation.

Dillard is able to play with them because she shares this passion for wholehearted engagement. Her "boy's arm" in baseball and her eagerness to participate in snowball fights demonstrate her willingness to embrace the boys' code of physicality and courage.

**2. What is Dillard's main point? Where does she state it explicitly?**

Dillard's main point is the enduring power of fully committing oneself to an experience, regardless of its consequences. This is most explicitly stated in paragraph 23: "It was an immense discovery, pounding into my hot head with every sliding, joyous step, that this ordinary adult evidently knew what I thought only children who trained at football knew: that you have to fling yourself at what you're doing, you have to point yourself, forget yourself, aim, dive."

The chase itself, while exhilarating, is secondary to the revelation about the importance of complete immersion and commitment.

**3. Why did she write this if she did not like memoirs?**

While Dillard generally dislikes memoirs, this piece transcends a simple recounting of personal events. It uses the anecdote of the chase as a vehicle to explore a larger theme about the human experience. It's less about Dillard herself and more about the universal desire for passionate engagement.

**4. Did she throw iceballs indiscriminately? If she didn‚Äôt, why mention it?**

The text suggests they didn't throw iceballs indiscriminately. Dillard mentions their specific targeting of the Buick and the fact that they considered it unfair to throw an iceball directly at someone. This detail highlights the unexpectedness of the driver's reaction and reinforces the boys' (and Dillard's) own code of conduct within their games.

**5. Why did they not run after being caught?**

They didn't run after being caught because they understood the unspoken rules of the game. They had been caught fair and square, and further resistance would have been pointless and disrespectful. They accepted the consequences of their actions and submitted to the authority of the adult.

**Overall, "The Chase" is a powerful essay that uses a childhood memory to explore the deeper meaning of commitment and the exhilaration of fully engaging in an experience. It highlights the value of embracing challenges and pushing oneself beyond perceived limitations, even if it means facing consequences.**

The "Responding to Reading" questions are designed to encourage further reflection on the themes of the essay and their relevance to personal experiences and moral dilemmas. They prompt the reader to consider the balance between youthful exuberance and responsible behavior, and the appropriate consequences for transgressions.

2. Dillard's main point is that boys and girls have different ways of experiencing and enjoying the world around them. In winter, in the snow, there was neither baseball nor football, so the boys and I threw snowballs at passing cars. I got in trouble throwing snowballs, and have seldom been happier since." She was interested in examining the ways in which our experiences shape our perceptions of reality and how we can use these perceptions to make sense of our lives.
4. Dillard did not throw iceballs indiscriminately. She only threw them at passing cars when she was with a group of boys who were also throwing snowballs at cars. But how could the glory have lasted forever? We could have run 20 through every backyard in North America until we got to Panama.
But when he trapped us at the lip ofthe Panama Canal, what pre- cisely could he have done to prolong the drama ofthe chase and cap
its glory? I brooded about this for the next few years. He could only have friedMikey Fahey and me in boilingoil, say, or dismembered us piecemeal, or staked us to anthills. None of which I really wanted, and none ofwhich any adult was likely to do, even in the spirit of fun. He could only chew us out there in the Panamanian jungle, after
months or years of exalting pursuit. He could only begin, "You stupid kids," and continue in his ordinary Pittsburgh accent with his normal righteous anger and the usual common sense.
Ifin that snowy backyard the driver of the black Buick had cut 12 off our heads, Mikey's and mine, I would have died happy, for noth-
ing has required so much ofme since as being chased all over Pitts- burghin the middle of winter- running terrified, exhausted- by
this sainted, skinny, furious red-headed man who wished to have a word with us. I don't know how he found his way back to his car.

2. Dillard's main point revolves around the exhilaration and freedom of childhood play, particularly the thrill of being chased and the intensity of the experience. She explicitly states this when she reflects on the chase, noting that it was a significant and joyful moment in her childhood. The essence of her point can be found in her description of the chase and the feelings it evoked, particularly when she expresses that nothing has required as much of her since that experience.

3. Dillard wrote this essay despite her dislike for memoirs because she wanted to capture and convey the essence of a specific childhood experience that was both exhilarating and formative. By sharing this story, she reflects on the nature of childhood, the thrill of adventure, and the lessons learned through play, which may transcend the typical confines of a memoir.

4. Dillard did not throw iceballs indiscriminately; she mentions that the Fahey boys and she considered it unfair to actually throw an iceball at someone. However, she includes this detail to illustrate the playful and mischievous nature of childhood, as well as to set the scene for the events that unfold. It highlights the innocence and the boundaries of their play, contrasting with the seriousness of the adult's reaction later.

5. They did not run after being caught because they were exhausted and had nowhere else to go. The chase had been intense, and when the man finally caught them, they were left panting and bewildered in a backyard. The excitement of the chase had transformed into a moment of stillness and reflection.

Text:
Some boys taught me to play football. This was fine sport. You thought up a new strategy for every play and whispered it to the others. You went out for a pass, fooling everyone. Best, you got to throw yourself mightily at someone's running legs. Either you brought him down or you hit the ground flat out on your chin, with your arms empty before you. It was all or nothing. If you hesitated in fear, you would miss and get hurt: you would take a hard fall while the kid got away, or you would get kicked in the face while the kid got away. But if you flung yourself wholeheartedly at the back of his knees - if you gathered and joined body and soul and pointed them diving fearlessly -- then you likely wouldn't get hurt, and you'd stop the ball. Your fate, and your team's score, depended on your concentration and courage. Nothing girls did could compare with it.
Boys welcomed me at baseball, too, for I had, through enthusi- 2
astic practice, what was weirdly known as a boy's arm. In winter, in the snow, there was neither baseball nor football, so the boys and I threw snowballs at passing cars. I got in trouble throwing snowballs, and have seldom been happier since.
On one weekday morning after Christmas, six inches of new snow had just fallen. We were standing up to our boot tops in snow on a front yard on trafficked Reynolds Street, waiting forcars. The cars traveled Reynolds Street slowly and evenly; they were targets all but wrapped in red ribbons, cream puffs. We couldn't miss.
I was seven; the boys were eight, nine, and ten. The oldest two Fahey boys were there - Mikey and Peter - polite blond boys who
lived near me on Lloyd Street, and who already had four brothers and sisters. My parents approved Mikey and Peter Fahey. Chickie McBride was there, a tough kid, and Billy Paul and Mackie Kean
too, from across Reynolds, where the boys grew up dark and furi- ous, grew up skinny, knowing, and skilled.We had all drifted from our houses that morning looking for action, and had found it here on Reynolds Street.
It was cloudy but cold. The cars' tires laid behind them on the snowy street a complex trail of beige chunks like crenellated castle walls. I had stepped on some earlier; they squeaked. We could have wished for more traffic. When a car came, we all popped it one. In
the intervals between cars we reverted to the natural solitude of children.
I started making an iceball - a perfect iceball, from perfectly 6 white snow, perfectly spherical, and squeezed perfectly translucent
os no snow remained all the way through. (The Fahey boys and I considered it unfair actually to throw an iceball at somebody, but it had been known to happen.)
I had just embarked on the iceball project when we heard tire
chains come clanking from afar. A black Buick was moving toward us down the street. We all spread out, banged together some regu- lar snowballs, tookaim, and, when the Buickdrew nigh, fired.
A soft snowball hit the driver's windshield right before the
driver's face. It made a smashed star with a hump in the middle.
Often, of course, we hit our target, but this time, t h eonly time in
all of life, the car pulled overand stopped. Its wide black door opened;
a man got out of it, running. He didn't even close thecardoor.
He ran after us, and we ran away from him, up the snowy 01 Reynolds sidewalk. At the corner, I looked back; incredibly, he was
still after us. He was in city clothes: a suit and tie, street shoes.
Any normal adult would have quit, having sprung us into flight and made his point. This man was gaining on us. He was a thin man,
all action. Al of asudden, we were running for our lives.
Wordless, we split up. We were on our turf; we could lose our- 1 selves in the neighborhood backyards, everyone for himself. I paused and considered. Everyone had vanished except Mikey Fahey, who was just rounding the corner of a yellow brick house. Poor Mikey, I trailed him. 'The driver of the Buick sensibly picked the two of us to follow. The man apparently had all day.
He chased Mikey and me around the yellow house and up a 21 backyard path we knew by heart: under a low tree, up a bank, through a hedge, down some snowy steps, and across the grocery store's delivery driveway. We smashed through a gap in another hedge, entered a scruffy backyard and ran around its back porch
and tight between houses to Edgerton Avenue; we ran across Edgerton to an alley and up our own sliding woodpile to the Halls' front yard; he kept coming. We ran up Lloyd Street and wound through mazy backyards toward the steep hilltop at Willard and
Lang.
He chased us silently, block after block. He chased us silently
13 over picket fences, through thorny hedges, between houses, around garbage cans, and across streets. Every time I glanced back, chok-
ing for breath, I expected he would have quit. He must have been
as breathless as we were. His jacket strained over his body. It was
an immense discovery, pounding into my hot head with every slid-
ing, joyous step, that this ordinary adult evidently knew what I
thought only children who trained at football knew: that you have
to fling yourself at what you're doing, you have to point yourself, forget yourself, aim, dive.
Mikey and I had nowhere to go, in our own neighborhood or out
41
of it, but away from this man who was chasing us. He impelled us forward; we compelled him to follow our route. The air was cold; every breath tore my throat. We kept running, block after block; we kept improvising, backyard after backyard, running a frantic course and choosing ti simultaneously, failing always to find small places or hard places to slow him down, and discovering always, ex- hilarated, dismayed, that only bare speed could save us - for he would never give up, this man- and we were losing speed.
He chased us through the backyard labyrinths of ten blocks be- fore he caught us by our jackets. He caught us and we all stopped.
We three stood staggering, half blinded, coughing, in an ob-
16 scure hilltop backyard: a man in his twenties, a boy, a girl. He had released our jackets, our pursuer, our captor, our hero: he knew we weren't going anywhere. We all played by the rules. Mikey and I
unzipped our jackets. I pulled off my sopping mittens. Our tracks multiplied in the backyard's new snow. We had been breaking new snow all morning. We didn't look at each other. I was cherishing my excitement. The man's lower pants legs were wet; his cuffs were full of snow, and there was a prow of snow beneath them on his shoes and socks. Some trees bordered the little flat backyard, some messy winter trees. There was no one around: a clearing in a grove, and we the only players.
It was a long time before he could speak. I had some difficulty 71 at first recalling why we were there. My lips felt swollen; Icouldn't
see out of the sides of my eyes; I kept coughing.
"You stupid kids," he began perfunctorily. 18 We listened perfunctorily indeed, if we listened at all, for the 19 chewing out was redundant, a mere formality, and beside the point.
The point was that he had chased us passionately without giving
up, and so he had caught us. Now he came down to earth. I wanted
the glory to last forever.
But how could the glory have lasted forever? We could have run 20 through every backyard in North America until we got to Panama.

its glory? I brooded about this for the next few years. He could only have friedMikey Fahey and me in boilingoil, say, or dismembered us piecemeal, or staked us to anthills. None of which I really wanted, and none ofwhich any adult was likely to do, even in the spirit of fun. He could only chew us out there in the Panamanian jungle, after
months or years of exalting pursuit. He could only begin, "You stupid kids," and continue in his ordinary Pittsburgh accent with his normal righteous anger and the usual common sense.
Ifin that snowy backyard the driver of the black Buick had cut 12 off our heads, Mikey's and mine, I would have died happy, for noth-
ing has required so much ofme since as being chased all over Pitts- burghin the middle of winter- running terrified, exhausted- by
this sainted, skinny, furious red-headed man who wished to have a word with us. I don't know how he found his way back to his car.
